item.title: One-third of world's stunted children live in India: Report - Al Jazeera English
item.description:
One-third of world's stunted children live in India: Report  Al Jazeera English

A major study published on Thursday warned of a malnutrition crisis in almost every country in the world with India holding about one-third of the world's burden for stunting. Forty-six million children in India are stunted because of malnutrition and 25.5 million more are defined as "wasted" - meaning they do not weigh enough for their height, according to the Global Nutrition Report 2018. Worldwide, 150.8 million children are stunted and 50.5 million are "wasted", the report said. item.description:

More than four in 10 children drink sugary drinks every day and one in three never eat fruit every day, according to a global report that warns most countries are unlikely to meet nutrition targets. item.description:

Defined as low height-for-age, stunting affects one in three children in the developing world and carries severe, irreversible consequences for both physical health and cognitive function. item.description:

By AZM Anas DHAKA (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Scampering up the wall of his tin shack in Bangladesh's capital, three-year-old Rozzob Ali has the same combination of mischief, charm and boisterous energy as many other boys.
